John Milligan . ..

To an assembly of the freshman
class, Dr David M Robinson described
yesterday the work of his most recent excavations at the ancient city
of Olympus. Prefacing his talk with
an epitomic history of the city, as
gathered from Heredotus and other
sources, Dr Robinson showed slides
of his staff and excavations.
Among the members of the staff
was an architect, several Hopkins
graduate students, a photographer,
and a representative of the Greek
government. The staff was supplemented at one time by as many as
four hundred native workers, but on
this trip a shrinkage of funds would
not allow as many workers as formerly.
Showing several slides of the site
of Olympus from the air, the speaker

continued to describe the method of
ascertaining the location of the city.
Because it was

veled to the ground

by invaders, the trchaeologists were
able to find little

Wethered Barroll, president of Pi
Delta Epsilon, national honorary
journalism fraternity, announced on
Wednesday that Jack Handelsman
has been appointed chairman of a
committee to conduct a contest in the
high schools of Baltimore and vicinity.
This contest is to determine the
outstanding high school newspaper
in point of make-up, style and general presentation. The contest is a
revival of a former activity of the
fraternity.
It is hoped that this competition
will make for improved lower school
newspapers and also stimulate interest in the honorary organization.
A meeting of Pi Delta Epsilon will
be held sometime in the coming week.
No new men will be taken in at this
meeting as the last induction was
held in June, 1938, at which time all
possible candidates were considered.

Whirlwind rehearsals, and tryouts
of principals have continued every
night at the Barn beginning 7:30 for
the production of "She Loves Me
Not," by the Barnstormers. Casting
for the male parts is nearly complete,
and the names of those chosen for
lead roles will be announced by
Director John Desch on Sunday,
November 13.
"She Loves Me Not" is a satire on
Princeton, and enjoyed a successful
run on Broadway two years ago. It
was written by Howard Lindsay. The
production of the farce indicates the
intention of the Barnstormer troupe
to continue to produce comedy plays
for Barnstormer nights, long a tra-

ditional Hopkins activity.
Difficulty in, filling .the female lead
parts has been experienced, and Seymour Sacks, assistant, has tapped
dozens of sources in the past week to
find girls. Considerable talent, both
dancing and singing, is expected for
the lead, but R S McShane, president of the 'Stormers, expressed
every confidence that volunteers will
be available soon.
Students who have had any past
stage experience in prep or high
school are urged to attend try-outs.
Many parts will be considered unfilled until official notification on the
13th of November. Those who can
handle a saw, bevel, hammer and

chisel are advised to consult Sam
Greenstein, production manager, for
participation on the production staff.
The elaborate sets demanded by the
playwright will demand expert and
earnest work by carpenters, painters,
and decorators.
The publicity staff, headed by
Victor M Victoroff, will begin an extended program after November 15.
Students intrested are asked to drop
a note to box 1141 for assignments.
The Barnstormer Dramatics club
is an extra-curricular, varsity activity endorsed by the Administration.
Membership is qualified by election
by the group.

Debaters map

During the last two meetings of the
year, as is customary, the council
heard two authoritative discussions
on the subject. One was presented by
Dr Broadus Mitchell who, upholding
the negative, declared that withdrawal of government support would
lead to economic disaster. Dr W 0
Weyforth gave the second discussion
upholding the affirmative side. He
claimed that government stimulation
is only good as a temporary remedy,
and that too much of it will lead to
inflation causing the negative results to overshadow the positive. The
council then proceeded to dismember
their arguments. and build upon
them.
Two trips are being planned this
year. A Southern tour is being arranged by Arthur Maas, president of
the council, and a Northern trip, by
James Sfekas. Southern colleges,
such as the University of Miami„
University of Virginia, University of
Georgia, and Duke university are
being considered.
Among Northern colleges are Harvard university, Amherst college,
New York university, and Yale university.
In the near future the affirmative
argument will be completed. The
members of the council will then
spend their meetings in finding fallacies and constructive arguments for
their subjects.

Miles Feeds
engineers poetry

Reading portions from Kipling's
immortal "Gunga Din," Shakespeare's "MacBeth", and Carl Sandburg's "Cool Tombs," Professor L
Wardlaw Miles of the Johns Hopkins
English department stressed to a
gathering of the American Society
of Civil Engineers at Latrobe hall
last Thursday the importance of engineers studying good poetry.
Dr Miles contended that poems
such as those he read afford not only
enjoyment to students, but contribute
something towards their educational
background that ordinary books fail
to touch. He went on to illustrate
his point by commenting on various
poems and prose pieces.
Samuel Spragins, president of the
society, introduced Dr Miles.

In answer to this editorial, we ask a report from the
Council in its enforcement of the Honor system. We
would like to examine it to see how much it has done
without the aid and initiative of the Honor commission.
Armistice Day is usually
the signal for a long catalogue of the hopes and fears
of the peace movement today. Of course, the fight
against war is too pressing
to be confined to occasional
pieces. At a time when the world is just as close to the
abyss as it was in 1913, we had best put our faith in
specific peace programs rather than lengthy polemics
against war as an instrument of national policy.
During the coming week-end two peace conferences
will be held in Baltimore. The first of these is under
the auspices of the Maryland Peace Conference, the
second under those of the Keep Amreica Out of War
Congress. Both deserve the fullest support of all friends
of peace and democracy.
At this moment, however, we are, as true provincials, chiefly interested in the future of the peace movement on the Hopkins campus. Last spring there was set
up at the University a permanent peace committee designed, to carry out the work of last year's anti-war
strike.
We had hoped for much from this organization.
For there is much to be done. We are all of us confused
about the future of America's foreign policy. The peace
committee was expected to provide a series of lectures
and discussions led by various authorities on that subject. It was expected to plan a genuine anti-war program and to carry out that program in vigorous fashion.
Unfortunately this has not been the case. Our strictures against the peace committee as now contsituted
are too well-known to bear repetition here. In the face
of events which have rocked the peace of Europe, it has
remained quiescent.
The city-wide week-end peace conference should
be an impetus to better things. Out of them should
come a program of definite action for the Hopkins. We
hope the peace committee will take the cue.

CLAMORAMA
•

Scene. A Meeting room.
Richards was standing at the end
of the table twirling five keys from
a chain. Suddenly he pounded the
table.
"To hell with five thousand names
signed to a petition," he said. "We
have got to act in the best intrests
of the signers and ignore what they
think about this matter."
Whoopes was watching with the
adoring eyes of a true fraternity
brother, hanging on Richard's every
word.
Fish shifted in his seat eight times,
took his fingernails out of his mouth,
and timidly ventured, "Well they
have got a little something on their
side."
"They have not," Richards shouted.
"Yes, I guess they haven't," echoed
Fish.
Whoopes signed with fraternal admiration and whispered, "Amen."
Roehiney, Doeman, and Doakeston,
smiling from under red caps of
liberty, choroused, "Sit down."
The dOor opened again and Knight
walked in, greeted Richards and
Whoopes with the fraternity grip
and sat down.
"To get into present business,"
Richards said, pounding the table and
looking around the table through his
glasses, "I want to announce that the
Dean has presented the council with
a bit of artificial fruit, with the hopes
that we could keep it well polished."
He took an apple out of his pocket
and set it on the table in front of the
Dean's bust. It was labeled "The
Dean's Apple."
"In addition," Richards continued,
"the Dean has returned to us with
his approval the revised constitution
which we referred to him last week.
This means, of course, that it will go
into effect with or without the approval of the Students."
The last statement caused a tremendous outcry.
Whoopes, Knight, Fish, and Feelman all rushed up to the head of the
table in a frenzied demonstration of
approval. They slapped him on the
back, congratulated him, and finally
marched around the table in triumph.
The procession was stopped when,
much to his own annoyance, the keys
on Richard's vest dragged him off
balance and he nearly fell.
Roehiney, Doeman, and Doakeston
raged among themselves in one
corner of the room. Then they approached the table grimly.
Silence fell.
Doakeston rose, his eyes and his
hair flaming.
`q tell you we will fight this thing
to the limit, so help me, if we have
to call out a picket line."
"I will now read the newly revised
constitution," Richards continued.
"The Constitution of the Stooges
council.
ARTICLE 1
The name of this body shall be
the Stooges council.
ARTICLE 2
The object of this body shall be to
regulate all student extra-curricular
activities in their best intrests according to the wishes of the Dean,
and to represent the Dean before the
students.
ARTICLE 3
Open assemblies to obtain an expression of student sentiment on
matters of importance will be called
when necessary, i e, when the Dean
considers it expedient to call one, or
when the outcome looks sufficiently
likely on the Dean's side that the
risk may be taken. A number of
names on a petition cannot be considered cause to hold one.
ARTICLE 5
All fraternity brothers shall vote
as a bloc in support of any measures
advance by the one holding the highest office.
ARTICLE 6
This constitution may or may not
be observed if the best intrests of the
students are at stake and student
opinion conflicts with council opinion
as dictated by the Dean."
Richards laid down the constitution and said, "I want to add that we
intend to fight this thing hrough to
he last, and with the backing of the
Dean I think we can do it." With
that he pounded the table in such a
display of spirit that the Dean's apple
bounced nearly a half an inch off the
table.
"We will now take a vote on the
acceptance of the new constitution,"
Richards said with an air of smug

The Blue Jay Chirps Again
A recent victim of the Student
council purge has bounced back on
the campus. It seems as though the
Blue Jay has again invaded the postoffice boxes of a large number of the
student body. However, the first issue
of the magazine can hardly be called
a Hopkins periodical, for all its contained pertaining to the University
was a snapshot or two of the
campus. On the whole it was filled
with "stuff" that smelled to high
heaven, and which was evidently
written by the printer who published
the magazine because of the ads secured by last year's staff.
There's a rumor that the advertising agency cancelled the contract

BALTIMORE

after consulting Dean Berry and
learning of the status of the publication. However, the printers went
right ahead in spite of this and put
the edition out, and at the present
time are worrying like h— about
their money.
We've always favored a literary
magazine on the campus, and felt
that the administration made a mistake in purging it, but to say that
we approve of the tripe handed out
in the October copy would be hypocritical. The Blue Jay should be reinstated as a legal activity at the University, but we fear that if another
issue like the last one appears, the
matter is a dead issue.

New Yorker Likes Rudo
Jesse Linthicum printed in his column the other day the comments of
a New Yorker who refused to divulge his name, praising Charley
Rudo for his sparkling play Saturday
at Homewood. We quote from the
column:
"That game should have been called 'Swarthmore vs Rudo.' He must
have averaged four yards a try on
the offensive and he was in nine out
of every ten tackles on the defense.
Pound for pound he's as good as any
back I've seen all year."

•..for your benefit
Relentlessly a mechanical mouth at Bell Telephone Laboratories keeps talking...talking...
talking into this new type telephone. Other telephones
are being frozen, steamed, baked, lifted and dropped
into their cradles by machines.
Why all these laboratory tortures? Simply because
your telephone must prove it can take more use and
abuse than it will ever get in its normal lifetime.It must
be ready to give you the best possible telephone service.
Exhaustive testing of Bell System apparatus is one
reason you can depend on your telephone always.

Why not telephone home oftener?
Rates to most points are lowest any time
after 7 P. M. and all day Sunday.

!Religious series
A congregationalist parson, an
atheist in college, and present professor of sociology at Duke university—these were the titles with
which Rev Siegenthaler, president of
the Baltimore Federation of churches
introduced last Monday night's
speaker in the Religious lecture
series.
Dr Hornell Hart laid the foundation of his talk upon the fact that
there are two worlds in our lives:
the sensory, which values the sensations of the body; and the world of
inner images, which values those
abstracts such as love that can exist
even in the absence of the sensory
world.
Dr Hart deplored the sacrifice of
the present generation of the inner
values for those of the sensory world.
"Civilization cannot exist", he said,
"unless we preserve the integrity of
religion." However, at present religion has reached a new low ebb.
In speaking of the search for truth,
Dr Hart gave four methods. Empiricism, the method of the completely
sensory world trusts only to the
principle of observation. Memory is
our means of seeking truth from the
past, but results in "reactionism and
stagnation." The world of verbal abstraction, that of the logician and
philosopher is another means of
finding truth, but it inevitably leads
to skepticism.
Lastly, we have the method of the
mystic, pure religion; the mystic

who believes "thus saith the Lord."
"Can't we combine all four of these
methods of finding truth? The world
today needs faith. But it also needs
cooperativeness and integrity", said
Dr Hart.
"We could obtain these three conditions, if science and religion were
united in the fundamental law of the
universe, brotherhood. All religions
believe in this universal brotherhood;
we could easily have a united religion."
"The Contribution of the Catholic
Church to American Life," will be
the theme of the religious lecture to
be delivered next week by Dr Peter
Guilday, Pr,ofessor of American
church history at Catholic university. The lecture is to be held in Latrobe hall, Monday evening at 8:15.
Dr Guilday is recognized as an
authority on the affairs of the American church. His knowledge of the
subject is accredited abroad, as well
as in the United States, as he has
been the recipient of numerous forDr
eign honors and decorations.
Guilday is also the possessor of LLD,
LHD, and JUD degrees.

Wethered Barroll, president of Pi
Delta Epsilon, national honorary
journalism fraternity, announced on
Wednesday that Jack Handelsman
has been appointed chairman of a
committee to conduct a contest in the
high schools of Baltimore and vicinity.
This contest is to determine the
outstanding high school newspaper
in point of make-up, style and general presentation. The contest is a
revival of a former activity of the
fraternity.
It is hoped that this competition
will make for improved lower school
newspapers and also stimulate interest in the honorary organization.
A meeting of Pi Delta Epsilon will
be held sometime in the coming week.
No new men will be taken in at this
meeting as the last induction was
held in June, 1938, at which time all
possible candidates were considered.

Whirlwind rehearsals, and tryouts
of principals have continued every
night at the Barn beginning 7:30 for
the production of "She Loves Me
Not," by the Barnstormers. Casting
for the male parts is nearly complete,
and the names of those chosen for
lead roles will be announced by
Director John Desch on Sunday,
November 13.
"She Loves Me Not" is a satire on
Princeton, and enjoyed a successful
run on Broadway two years ago. It
was written by Howard Lindsay. The
production of the farce indicates the
intention of the Barnstormer troupe
to continue to produce comedy plays
for Barnstormer nights, long a tra-

ditional Hopkins activity.
Difficulty in, filling .the female lead
parts has been experienced, and Seymour Sacks, assistant, has tapped
dozens of sources in the past week to
find girls. Considerable talent, both
dancing and singing, is expected for
the lead, but R S McShane, president of the 'Stormers, expressed
every confidence that volunteers will
be available soon.
Students who have had any past
stage experience in prep or high
school are urged to attend try-outs.
Many parts will be considered unfilled until official notification on the
13th of November. Those who can
handle a saw, bevel, hammer and

chisel are advised to consult Sam
Greenstein, production manager, for
participation on the production staff.
The elaborate sets demanded by the
playwright will demand expert and
earnest work by carpenters, painters,
and decorators.
The publicity staff, headed by
Victor M Victoroff, will begin an extended program after November 15.
Students intrested are asked to drop
a note to box 1141 for assignments.
The Barnstormer Dramatics club
is an extra-curricular, varsity activity endorsed by the Administration.
Membership is qualified by election
by the group.

During the last two meetings of the
year, as is customary, the council
heard two authoritative discussions
on the subject. One was presented by
Dr Broadus Mitchell who, upholding
the negative, declared that withdrawal of government support would
lead to economic disaster. Dr W 0
Weyforth gave the second discussion
upholding the affirmative side. He
claimed that government stimulation
is only good as a temporary remedy,
and that too much of it will lead to
inflation causing the negative results to overshadow the positive. The
council then proceeded to dismember
their arguments. and build upon
them.
Two trips are being planned this
year. A Southern tour is being arranged by Arthur Maas, president of
the council, and a Northern trip, by
James Sfekas. Southern colleges,
such as the University of Miami„
University of Virginia, University of
Georgia, and Duke university are
being considered.
Among Northern colleges are Harvard university, Amherst college,
New York university, and Yale university.
In the near future the affirmative
argument will be completed. The
members of the council will then
spend their meetings in finding fallacies and constructive arguments for
their subjects.

Miles Feeds
engineers poetry

Reading portions from Kipling's
immortal "Gunga Din," Shakespeare's "MacBeth", and Carl Sandburg's "Cool Tombs," Professor L
Wardlaw Miles of the Johns Hopkins
English department stressed to a
gathering of the American Society
of Civil Engineers at Latrobe hall
last Thursday the importance of engineers studying good poetry.
Dr Miles contended that poems
such as those he read afford not only
enjoyment to students, but contribute
something towards their educational
background that ordinary books fail
to touch. He went on to illustrate
his point by commenting on various
poems and prose pieces.
Samuel Spragins, president of the
society, introduced Dr Miles.

In answer to this editorial, we ask a report from the
Council in its enforcement of the Honor system. We
would like to examine it to see how much it has done

Armistice Day is usually
the signal for a long catalogue of the hopes and fears
of the peace movement today. Of course, the fight
against war is too pressing
to be confined to occasional
pieces. At a time when the world is just as close to the
abyss as it was in 1913, we had best put our faith in
specific peace programs rather than lengthy polemics
against war as an instrument of national policy.
During the coming week-end two peace conferences
will be held in Baltimore. The first of these is under
the auspices of the Maryland Peace Conference, the
second under those of the Keep Amreica Out of War
Congress. Both deserve the fullest support of all friends
of peace and democracy.
At this moment, however, we are, as true provincials, chiefly interested in the future of the peace movement on the Hopkins campus. Last spring there was set
up at the University a permanent peace committee designed, to carry out the work of last year's anti-war
strike.
We had hoped for much from this organization.
For there is much to be done. We are all of us confused
about the future of America's foreign policy. The peace
committee was expected to provide a series of lectures
and discussions led by various authorities on that subject. It was expected to plan a genuine anti-war program and to carry out that program in vigorous fashion.
Unfortunately this has not been the case. Our strictures against the peace committee as now contsituted
are too well-known to bear repetition here. In the face
of events which have rocked the peace of Europe, it has
remained quiescent.
The city-wide week-end peace conference should
be an impetus to better things. Out of them should
come a program of definite action for the Hopkins. We
hope the peace committee will take the cue.

CLAMORAMA

Scene. A Meeting room.
Richards was standing at the end
of the table twirling five keys from
a chain. Suddenly he pounded the
table.
"To hell with five thousand names
signed to a petition," he said. "We
have got to act in the best intrests
of the signers and ignore what they
think about this matter."
Whoopes was watching with the
adoring eyes of a true fraternity
brother, hanging on Richard's every
word.
Fish shifted in his seat eight times,
took his fingernails out of his mouth,
and timidly ventured, "Well they
have got a little something on their
side."
"They have not," Richards shouted.
"Yes, I guess they haven't," echoed
Fish.
Whoopes signed with fraternal admiration and whispered, "Amen."
Roehiney, Doeman, and Doakeston,
smiling from under red caps of
liberty, choroused, "Sit down."
The dOor opened again and Knight
walked in, greeted Richards and
Whoopes with the fraternity grip
and sat down.
"To get into present business,"
Richards said, pounding the table and
looking around the table through his
glasses, "I want to announce that the
Dean has presented the council with
a bit of artificial fruit, with the hopes
that we could keep it well polished."
He took an apple out of his pocket
and set it on the table in front of the
Dean's bust. It was labeled "The
Dean's Apple."
"In addition," Richards continued,
"the Dean has returned to us with
his approval the revised constitution
which we referred to him last week.
This means, of course, that it will go
into effect with or without the approval of the Students."
The last statement caused a tremendous outcry.
Whoopes, Knight, Fish, and Feelman all rushed up to the head of the
table in a frenzied demonstration of
approval. They slapped him on the
back, congratulated him, and finally
marched around the table in triumph.
The procession was stopped when,
much to his own annoyance, the keys
on Richard's vest dragged him off
balance and he nearly fell.
Roehiney, Doeman, and Doakeston
raged among themselves in one
corner of the room. Then they approached the table grimly.
Silence fell.
Doakeston rose, his eyes and his
hair flaming.
`q tell you we will fight this thing
to the limit, so help me, if we have
to call out a picket line."
"I will now read the newly revised
constitution," Richards continued.
"The Constitution of the Stooges
council.
ARTICLE 1
The name of this body shall be
the Stooges council.
ARTICLE 2
The object of this body shall be to
regulate all student extra-curricular
activities in their best intrests according to the wishes of the Dean,
and to represent the Dean before the
students.
ARTICLE 3
Open assemblies to obtain an expression of student sentiment on
matters of importance will be called
when necessary, i e, when the Dean
considers it expedient to call one, or
when the outcome looks sufficiently
likely on the Dean's side that the
risk may be taken. A number of
names on a petition cannot be considered cause to hold one.
ARTICLE 5
All fraternity brothers shall vote
as a bloc in support of any measures
advance by the one holding the highest office.
ARTICLE 6
This constitution may or may not
be observed if the best intrests of the
students are at stake and student
opinion conflicts with council opinion
as dictated by the Dean."
Richards laid down the constitution and said, "I want to add that we
intend to fight this thing hrough to

The Blue Jay Chirps Again
A recent victim of the Student
council purge has bounced back on
the campus. It seems as though the
Blue Jay has again invaded the postoffice boxes of a large number of the
student body. However, the first issue
of the magazine can hardly be called
a Hopkins periodical, for all its contained pertaining to the University
was a snapshot or two of the
campus. On the whole it was filled
with "stuff" that smelled to high
heaven, and which was evidently
written by the printer who published
the magazine because of the ads secured by last year's staff.
There's a rumor that the advertising agency cancelled the contract

BALTIMORE

after consulting Dean Berry and
learning of the status of the publication. However, the printers went
right ahead in spite of this and put
the edition out, and at the present
time are worrying like h— about
their money.
We've always favored a literary
magazine on the campus, and felt
that the administration made a mistake in purging it, but to say that
we approve of the tripe handed out
in the October copy would be hypocritical. The Blue Jay should be reinstated as a legal activity at the University, but we fear that if another
issue like the last one appears, the
matter is a dead issue.

Rudo for his sparkling play Saturday

back I've seen all year."

•..for your benefit
Relentlessly a mechanical mouth at Bell Telephone Laboratories keeps talking...talking...
talking into this new type telephone. Other telephones
are being frozen, steamed, baked, lifted and dropped
into their cradles by machines.
Why all these laboratory tortures? Simply because
your telephone must prove it can take more use and
abuse than it will ever get in its normal lifetime.It must
be ready to give you the best possible telephone service.
Exhaustive testing of Bell System apparatus is one
reason you can depend on your telephone always.

Why not telephone home oftener?
Rates to most points are lowest any time
after 7 P. M. and all day Sunday.

!Religious series
A congregationalist parson, an
atheist in college, and present professor of sociology at Duke university—these were the titles with
which Rev Siegenthaler, president of
the Baltimore Federation of churches
introduced last Monday night's
speaker in the Religious lecture
series.
Dr Hornell Hart laid the foundation of his talk upon the fact that
there are two worlds in our lives:
the sensory, which values the sensations of the body; and the world of
inner images, which values those
abstracts such as love that can exist
even in the absence of the sensory
world.
Dr Hart deplored the sacrifice of
the present generation of the inner
values for those of the sensory world.
"Civilization cannot exist", he said,
"unless we preserve the integrity of
religion." However, at present religion has reached a new low ebb.
In speaking of the search for truth,
Dr Hart gave four methods. Empiricism, the method of the completely
sensory world trusts only to the
principle of observation. Memory is
our means of seeking truth from the
past, but results in "reactionism and
stagnation." The world of verbal abstraction, that of the logician and
philosopher is another means of
finding truth, but it inevitably leads
to skepticism.
Lastly, we have the method of the
mystic, pure religion; the mystic

who believes "thus saith the Lord."
"Can't we combine all four of these
methods of finding truth? The world
today needs faith. But it also needs
cooperativeness and integrity", said
Dr Hart.
"We could obtain these three conditions, if science and religion were
united in the fundamental law of the
universe, brotherhood. All religions
believe in this universal brotherhood;
we could easily have a united religion."
"The Contribution of the Catholic
Church to American Life," will be
the theme of the religious lecture to
be delivered next week by Dr Peter
Guilday, Pr,ofessor of American
church history at Catholic university. The lecture is to be held in Latrobe hall, Monday evening at 8:15.
Dr Guilday is recognized as an
authority on the affairs of the American church. His knowledge of the
subject is accredited abroad, as well
as in the United States, as he has
been the recipient of numerous forDr
eign honors and decorations.
Guilday is also the possessor of LLD,
LHD, and JUD degrees.
